bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 7, 1941

div1.p: Kean discusses withholding some confidential material from Laura Wood Roper and recommends Kissinger enter a Veteran's Bureau Hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 7, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
July 7th 1941
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of the 26th was
full of interest and deserves a
longer letter in answer than I
am able to write this morning,
but I am not going to defer any
longer to write. It came on the
30th which happened to be a busy
day. I do not have many which
deserve to be so called. The next
the old pump which hasd served
me so faithfully for 81 years and
3 days began to cut up and inter-
mit & go now fast, now slow & then
very weak and I had to go on sick
report and take digitalis, and try
AC
K
2
to take it easy especially as the temp.
went to 97°F with humidity ranging
between 55 and 84%. July 2nd I was
much better but the heat was
even worse reaching 98°F after a
night when the weir did not get below
79°F. Miss Laura Wood came to see
me but I was unable to see her.
She has gone to the sea shore for the
month of July and when Mrs. Kean
told her that she tried to tell her
of my illness but was unable to
get her on the phone, she explained
that the phone was in her husband's
name which was Mr. W. C. Roper.
Just why she prefers not to use
his name she did not say.
She seems to be a very intelligent
capable & nice looking young woman
straight forward & business like with no fem-
inine airs or what the
3
young people of the present day call S. A.
If you are good enough to let her have
such of your abundant material as you
can with convenience to yourself I
believe she will make good use
of it and return any USS which you
may request. Do not however let her
have any confidential material
such as Reed's letter to Gen. Sternburg
about the Pinar del Rio doctors.
This I think you had better not
print yourself. Some of them are
still alive probably and one, Dr. Cooke
has redeemed himself & is in the Y. F.
Roll of Honor of which you have promised
to be a defender. I will give your
name and address to Brig. Gen. A.G.
Love, Med. Corps. the Surgeon General's
Assistant (who will soon retire for
age unfortunately). He will arrange
to have you notified if any thing
comes up in Congress, like the Poucher
case. I think you are a wonder to
have located the S. G. O. correspondence
at Fort Meyer Mr. Brooks can
find what you want if any one can
but I think it may be like the Irish
Sea-cook's Kettle - a story which I will
tell you three time if you don't know it.
Thanks for the snap shots of Gen. Ireland
and me. I showed them to him an
hour ago when he was here for a chat.
He is very good about coming to see
me quite often as for 39 years we have been
very close friends. I let him see your
letter and he says that Kissinger should
go to a Veteran's Bureau Hospital.
They have a good one at Indianapolis
There would be no charges there for him.

I have just called General Walter Law-
rence Reed to ask the news of his Sister
Blossom. He says that her attack was
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
functional and of nervous origin and
the doctor in charge is quite
confident that her heart trouble, which
has passed, was not organic in character
They are keeping her quiet & in bed
but are not worried about her.
He says his mother who is now 85
is in fine health and spirits.

The photograph of the group at Mariel
intriges me greatly. Of course I recog-
nize the three that you already know
which are by the way excellent likenesses of
Dr. Finlay Dr Guiteras & Dr Agramonte. I think
the one in the white helmet on the left may be
Dr. Lopez del Valle and the two standing behind Drs
Finlay & Guiteras dressed in white look very
familiar to me, as does the one in black
behind Guiteras. But I cannot call
their names. Lopez del Valle died only
a few months ago as did my good
and devoted friend Dr. Jose M. Peña.
I must stop here as lunch is waiting
